title: If I'm writing in a first person perspective, what's the best way to know about it? - Quora

response.answer_text: When you write in first person, you are an unreliable narrator. You can only write what your character knows, thinks or guesses. You can’t tell the reader what any other character knows. And as you are writing first person, it’s pretty much stream of consciousness. Just as you don’t think, “I’m going to meet Jenny, who I first met when we were in first grade and I liked her lunch box and she pulled my braids” you can’t write it. Your first person character can only think the sort of thing you would think, which is likely to be, “I hope Jenny remembers that tenner she owes me.” Writing first person is actually a great tool to avoid infodumps and exposition. Make the most of it.

You can’t write from first person perspective unless you have experience or are reporting on an event by interviewing those who have experienced the event or situation and you could then write about the experience of interviewing them. If you are writing fiction from a first person perspective of a character then you can write only what the character has experienced or heard or been told.
